title: BTreeSet causes UB by having (partially) dangling shared reference

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: I-unsound
labels.description: Issue: A soundness hole (worst kind of bug), see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soundness

body:
The following code causes UB (found by a patched miri enforcing validity invariants):
```rust
    let mut b = std::collections::BTreeSet::new();
    b.insert(42);
```
What happens is that `BTreeSet::new` [sets the root node](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/4623d4889373702428251967d9bf6ff6d677ec1a/src/liballoc/collections/btree/map.rs#L535) to [a pointer to](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/4623d4889373702428251967d9bf6ff6d677ec1a/src/liballoc/collections/btree/node.rs#L197) a [static `EMPTY_ROOT_NODE` shared for this purpose by all B-trees](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/4623d4889373702428251967d9bf6ff6d677ec1a/src/liballoc/collections/btree/node.rs#L116) that has type `LeafNode<(), ()>`. That step is okay.

However, in the next step, `insert` calls [`ensure_root_is_owned`](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/4623d4889373702428251967d9bf6ff6d677ec1a/src/liballoc/collections/btree/map.rs#L1174) which indirectly [turns this ptr](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/4623d4889373702428251967d9bf6ff6d677ec1a/src/liballoc/collections/btree/node.rs#L388) into `&LeafNode<i32, ()>`. The trouble is that `LeafNode<i32, ()>` is bigger than `LeafNode<(), ()>`, so this reference is partially dangling: Its beginning points to allocated memory (the static `EMPTY_ROOT_NODE`), but that allocated memory ends "too early". The invariant that `&LeafNode<i32, ()>` be dereferencable *for `mem::size_of::<LeafNode<i32, ()>>()` bytes* is violated. Since we are passing `dereferencable(n)` to LLVM [with `n` set to the full size of the struct](https://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=8c9fecbcecd4896eaa7d2a97686714da&version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2015), this means we have UB not just according to our own validity rules, but according to LLVM's rules.
